awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Open-Source Data Analytics for Distribution Systems Management and Operations
awd_abstract_narration:
Distribution system operations (DSO) are designed to maintain reliability in the presence of predictable variability. Future distribution systems will operate in a dramatically different environment with deep penetration of distributed energy resources (e.g. solar, EVs, storage, smart loads) and widespread adoption of novel devices for network management resulting in increased variability. Unless DSO can be adapted to these conditions, performance and revenues of future utilities will be severely impaired. How to adapt Future systems will generate a wealth of data from consumers, line sensors and network equipment. Utilizing this data for learning, prediction and resource coordination is challenging and not fully understood. This proposal seeks to connect "bits to watts" utilizing modern data analytics in order to enable scalable and cost effective DSO for future distribution networks. In particular the proposal explores new approaches in machine learning, optimization and behavior learning and their applications in power systems. The methods will be implemented in a software platform: Visualization and Insight for Demand Operations and Management (VISDOM). The research component of the proposal will enable emissions reductions and massive scaling of the management of behind the meter resources. It contributes to the budding smart grid data analytics industry expected to reach a $6 billion market size by 2020. The education component of the proposal will create a novel curriculum and online education in data thinking to prepare the data analytics workforce of the future. 

The project will make use of large spatial and temporal data sets from industry and utilities to explore new approaches in machine learning, stochastic control & optimization and behavioral economics to address problems in power systems. The central problems that will be addressed are: (i) Build an adaptive consumer behavior learning framework that scales to large numbers of consumers; (ii) Investigate probabilistic demand forecasting and pricing methods at multiple scales ranging from individual residential consumers to communities; (iii) Develop a novel network reconstruction and monitoring framework to learn the power distribution network from data; (iv) Create data and simulation driven placement and coordination mechanisms for residential demand-side resources; and (v) Utilize an interactive platform that engages consumers in real-time to develop novel randomized trial approaches and apply it to innovative behavioral programs. Impacts such as increasing the value of consumer demand flexibility by more than 50% are expected. The resulting methods will be made available in open-source in the VISDOM platform.  VISDOM can support a thriving community of academics and industry partners that experiment with demand side management. Currently, every project develops non-transparent and limited analysis mechanisms that consume time and resources. More broadly, the time-series data based approaches developed in this proposal are applicable to other fields such as marketing, healthcare and e-commerce. The education component will advance concepts from data thinking into power systems. The proposed curriculum includes a new hands-on course in data analytics for energy systems for undergraduate and masters students; online adult education courses directed at utility professionals and a broader audience and a K12 experimental practicum prepared with high school teachers visiting the PI's lab in a summer program. In addition, a smart grid seminar involving distinguished speakers from academia and industry will be supported and made available online.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
Open-Source Data Analytics for Distribution Systems Management and Operations

Our project set out to revolutionize power distribution systems management by leveraging open-source data analytics. We aimed to develop innovative methods to understand consumer behavior, enhance demand forecasting, optimize distributed energy resources (DERs), and improve the overall efficiency and reliability of the power grid.


One of our primary achievements was advancing consumer load modeling. Traditional models often rely on simplistic assumptions that fail to capture the diversity and complexity of actual consumer behavior. By utilizing vast amounts of smart meter data, we developed data-driven models that more accurately reflect how different households use electricity. As a result, utilities can better target and segment consumers, enhancing demand-side management strategies and improving the coordination of DERs.


We also tackled the challenge of mapping solar panel adoption. With the rapid increase in rooftop and community-scale photovoltaic installations, accurate tracking is essential to predict adoption trends and assess grid impacts. Traditional methods of collecting installation data are slow and often incomplete. We addressed this by creating a scalable model that detects solar panels from satellite imagery using deep learning techniques. Our model successfully mapped solar installations across the United States, providing valuable insights into adoption patterns. 


Understanding electric vehicle (EV) charging behavior was another critical component of our project. With the increasing popularity of EVs, it's essential to comprehend how charging patterns affect the power grid. We analyzed millions of real-world EV charging sessions to develop a model that captures the diverse behaviors of EV owners. Unlike theoretical models that assume rational decision-making, our data-driven approach revealed varying levels of risk aversion and non-rational behaviors among consumers. This nuanced understanding helps utilities anticipate the impact of EV charging on the grid and plan accordingly.

Recognizing the importance of reliable distribution network models, we developed methods to reconstruct network topology and parameters directly from data. Obtaining accurate power flow models is often time-consuming and expensive. By leveraging data from smart meters and Advanced Distribution Management Systems, we created tools that learn network configurations and parameters. These tools not only improve reliability but also facilitate the optimal placement of storage devices and enhance grid resilience.

Privacy concerns are a significant barrier to utilizing detailed consumer data. Traditional privacy approaches often degrade the utility of data for tasks like energy optimization. We addressed this by developing a novel method for sharing time-series data that preserves individual privacy without sacrificing performance.  


Optimizing DER coordination was another focus area. Uncoordinated DERs can lead to inefficiencies and missed opportunities for services like peak load reduction. We assessed the value of coordinating DERs and developed practical algorithms to facilitate this process. Our research demonstrated that effective coordination could dramatically reduce the need for costly system upgrades due to increased electrification and DER adoption. For instance, we found that with proper coordination, only 30% of transformers would need replacement by 2040, compared to 90% without it.


To enhance forecasting capabilities, we introduced NeuralProphet, a deep learning approach that builds upon existing time-series modeling methods. This tool provides accurate and computationally efficient predictions and has been released as open-source software. It has gained significant traction, aiding various stakeholders in making informed decisions based on reliable forecasts.


We also explored the nexus between water and energy consumption. Applying our data analytics techniques to water usage, we developed models of individual consumer responses to events and helps utilities assess the effectiveness of interventions and demand management programs.  

Beyond our research achievements, we made significant contributions to education and outreach. We established the "Data Thinking" framework to educate diverse audiences about electricity data science. Through a summer workshop, we engaged over 100 young students in analyzing their home energy use, fostering energy literacy from an early age.  


We integrated course modules into university curricula, offering classes like "AI for Climate Change" and "Engineering the Future of Electricity Systems" to undergraduate and graduate students. These courses provided hands-on experiences in artificial intelligence and data analytics applied to energy systems. Additionally, we developed an online continuing education program titled "Transforming the Grid: AI, Renewables, Storage, EVs, and Prosumers," which has trained over 1,000 participants, including policymakers and industry leaders.
Our work has been widely disseminated through high-profile publications in journals like IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid and Nature Energy. We also shared our code and tools on platforms like GitHub, enabling widespread access to advanced analytics methods.

By engaging with non-profits, industry partners, and media outlets, we fostered collaborations that contributed to building a community focused on smart grid development and sustainable energy solutions.
In conclusion, this project has significantly advanced the field of distribution systems management by integrating open-source data analytics with practical applications. Through innovative modeling techniques and a commitment to education and collaboration, we have addressed critical challenges in energy systems.  


Last Modified: 10/07/2024
Modified by: Ram Rajagopal
por.por_txt_cntn:
Open-Source Data Analytics for Distribution Systems Management and Operations


Our project set out to revolutionize power distribution systems management by leveraging open-source data analytics. We aimed to develop innovative methods to understand consumer behavior, enhance demand forecasting, optimize distributed energy resources (DERs), and improve the overall efficiency and reliability of the power grid.



One of our primary achievements was advancing consumer load modeling. Traditional models often rely on simplistic assumptions that fail to capture the diversity and complexity of actual consumer behavior. By utilizing vast amounts of smart meter data, we developed data-driven models that more accurately reflect how different households use electricity. As a result, utilities can better target and segment consumers, enhancing demand-side management strategies and improving the coordination of DERs.



We also tackled the challenge of mapping solar panel adoption. With the rapid increase in rooftop and community-scale photovoltaic installations, accurate tracking is essential to predict adoption trends and assess grid impacts. Traditional methods of collecting installation data are slow and often incomplete. We addressed this by creating a scalable model that detects solar panels from satellite imagery using deep learning techniques. Our model successfully mapped solar installations across the United States, providing valuable insights into adoption patterns.



Understanding electric vehicle (EV) charging behavior was another critical component of our project. With the increasing popularity of EVs, it's essential to comprehend how charging patterns affect the power grid. We analyzed millions of real-world EV charging sessions to develop a model that captures the diverse behaviors of EV owners. Unlike theoretical models that assume rational decision-making, our data-driven approach revealed varying levels of risk aversion and non-rational behaviors among consumers. This nuanced understanding helps utilities anticipate the impact of EV charging on the grid and plan accordingly.


Recognizing the importance of reliable distribution network models, we developed methods to reconstruct network topology and parameters directly from data. Obtaining accurate power flow models is often time-consuming and expensive. By leveraging data from smart meters and Advanced Distribution Management Systems, we created tools that learn network configurations and parameters. These tools not only improve reliability but also facilitate the optimal placement of storage devices and enhance grid resilience.


Privacy concerns are a significant barrier to utilizing detailed consumer data. Traditional privacy approaches often degrade the utility of data for tasks like energy optimization. We addressed this by developing a novel method for sharing time-series data that preserves individual privacy without sacrificing performance.



Optimizing DER coordination was another focus area. Uncoordinated DERs can lead to inefficiencies and missed opportunities for services like peak load reduction. We assessed the value of coordinating DERs and developed practical algorithms to facilitate this process. Our research demonstrated that effective coordination could dramatically reduce the need for costly system upgrades due to increased electrification and DER adoption. For instance, we found that with proper coordination, only 30% of transformers would need replacement by 2040, compared to 90% without it.



To enhance forecasting capabilities, we introduced NeuralProphet, a deep learning approach that builds upon existing time-series modeling methods. This tool provides accurate and computationally efficient predictions and has been released as open-source software. It has gained significant traction, aiding various stakeholders in making informed decisions based on reliable forecasts.



We also explored the nexus between water and energy consumption. Applying our data analytics techniques to water usage, we developed models of individual consumer responses to events and helps utilities assess the effectiveness of interventions and demand management programs.


Beyond our research achievements, we made significant contributions to education and outreach. We established the "Data Thinking" framework to educate diverse audiences about electricity data science. Through a summer workshop, we engaged over 100 young students in analyzing their home energy use, fostering energy literacy from an early age.



We integrated course modules into university curricula, offering classes like "AI for Climate Change" and "Engineering the Future of Electricity Systems" to undergraduate and graduate students. These courses provided hands-on experiences in artificial intelligence and data analytics applied to energy systems. Additionally, we developed an online continuing education program titled "Transforming the Grid: AI, Renewables, Storage, EVs, and Prosumers," which has trained over 1,000 participants, including policymakers and industry leaders.
Our work has been widely disseminated through high-profile publications in journals like IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid and Nature Energy. We also shared our code and tools on platforms like GitHub, enabling widespread access to advanced analytics methods.


By engaging with non-profits, industry partners, and media outlets, we fostered collaborations that contributed to building a community focused on smart grid development and sustainable energy solutions.
In conclusion, this project has significantly advanced the field of distribution systems management by integrating open-source data analytics with practical applications. Through innovative modeling techniques and a commitment to education and collaboration, we have addressed critical challenges in energy systems.					Last Modified: 10/07/2024
